Energy Rev. 57:1568-1579 70% of primary energy consumption wasted as heat current inorganic materials: - toxic - not abundant - costly processing (melt-spinning, hot pressing, ball milling) - heavy and brittle organic materials: - none of the above - additionally intrinsically low thermal conductivityPHAS0058, Lecture 4 Dr Monika Szumilo Seebeck and Peltier effect Seebeck effectPeltier effectPHAS0058, Lecture 4 Dr Monika Szumilo Characterisation of thermoelectrics â€¢ S- Seebeck coefficient (thermopower) â€¢ Tâ€“ temperature â€¢ Vâ€“ voltage â€¢ Qâ€“ heat â€¢ Ï€- Peltier coefficient â€¢ I- current from 1 to 2 â€¢ Î² â€“ Thomson coefficient â€¢ ZTâ€“ figure of merit â€¢ Ïƒ â€“ electrical conductivity â€¢ Îº â€“ thermal conductivity â€¢ PFâ€“ power factor Seebeck equation Peltier effect Thomson effect Figure of merit TEG efficiency ğ‘†=ğ‘‰âˆ’ ğ‘‰ ğ‘‡âˆ’ ğ‘‡ ğ‘„ = ğœ‹âˆ’ ğœ‹ ğ¼ ğ‘„ = ğ›½ğ¼ Î”ğ‘‡ ğ‘ğ‘‡ = ğ‘† ğœğ‘‡ ğœ… ğœ‚ = ğ‘‡âˆ’ ğ‘‡ ğ‘‡ 1 + ğ‘ğ‘‡ âˆ’ 1 1 + ğ‘ğ‘‡ + ğ‘‡ ğ‘‡ ğ‘ƒğ¹=ğ‘†ğœPHAS0058, Lecture 4 Dr Monika Szumilo Organic thermoelectrics Challenges: â€¢ low charge mobilities â€¢ inferior Seebeck coefficients â€¢ best materials usually organic-inorganic hybrids Opportunities: â€¢ anisotropic transport â€¢ mW power extracted at 10K temperature difference â€¢ flexibility â€¢ body compatibility (non-toxic)PHAS0058, Lecture 4 Dr Monika Szumilo Body heat application Wang, Y., Zhou, Z., Zhou, J., Shao, L., Wang, Y., Deng, Y.,.
